@guozhangwang thanks for the review.  I'll move the fix to the `StreamPartitionAssignor#onAssignment` .  

From what I can see we'll need to leave the to call to `TopologyBuilder.updateSubscription` in `StreamPartitionAssignor#subscription()` as it updates the leader's topology  used in the`StreamPartitionAssignor.assign` method.

Test FAILed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

I agree that moving the BufferSupplier to the Fetcher is ultimately the right thing to do, but it feels like we're going through great lengths to avoid ThreadLocals when we are already indirectly making use of them in the Snappy case, through [`SnappyOutputStream`'s default `BufferAllocator`](https://github.com/xerial/snappy-java/blob/master/src/main/java/org/xerial/snappy/buffer/CachedBufferAllocator.java).

The server side could equally benefit from the performance improvements during compaction.

Would it be ok to wait for a more comprehensive solution to removing the ThreadLocals on both server and client side across all compression schemes? I feel we are unnecessarily picking on the LZ4 case, and unless there are real concerns with introducing ThreadLocal's on the consumer side, I don't feel we have a good reason not to do so.

Otherwise, all the other small changes in the PR look good to me.

@xvrl, the `Snappy` link doesn't seem to have any thread locals? It seems like a static buffer cache that relies on soft references.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4561/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

@ijuma oops, I was looking at different version of the code here https://github.com/dain/snappy/blob/master/src/main/java/org/iq80/snappy/BufferRecycler.java but the idea is the same. If anything, using a threadlocal is better in that case since the entries would be released as soon as the thread dies, rather than with a simple softreference, which would only be collected if memory pressure gets high enough.

> From what I can see we'll need to leave the to call to TopologyBuilder.updateSubscription in StreamPartitionAssignor#subscription() as it updates the leader's topology used in theStreamPartitionAssignor.assign method.

makes sense.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/4546/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

@xvrl, the second link is for a different pure Java Snappy library that we don't use. So, to be clear, we are not currently relying on thread locals. There are pros and cons for thread local versus global caches, but let's leave that discussion for another time. :)

With regards to the path forward for the 0.11.0.0 release, I think it makes sense to go with the lowest risk solution that gives us the huge gains you outlined in your PR. From that perspective, I think it's actually a benefit that this version doesn't affect the broker. By limiting this to the `Fetcher` and via a `BufferSupplier` that has the same lifecycle as `Fetcher`,  it reduces the risk.

I agree that there are a number of improvements we can do in the broker for reducing buffer allocation costs and we should pursue those for the next release (along with KIP-72).

Thoughts?

```
Execution failed for task ':core:compileTestScala'.

```

@guozhangwang Noticed you merged the PR at [https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3100](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3100). As I mentioned in a KAFKA-5278 [comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-5278?focusedCommentId=16017556&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16017556), that PR addresses only a subset of the issue reported in [KAFK-3982](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3982) and this fix. For example, you can see the unit test added in this patch fails in the current trunk.

retest this please

@vahidhashemian Good to know! 

Though I'm wondering if we should ever change the serde configs in the new consumer, as it is always using `byte[], byte[]` as the key value types, and rely on the message formatter to deserialize the message. So I think we should bypass the user specified configs into `message.formatter` configs but leave the consumer's configs as `byteDeserializer`?

Is it sufficient to only synchronize on these two functions? Say I have a `put` call concurrently with the `putIfAbsent` call, then it is still possible that the `put` call will take place after `get` but before `put` inside the `putIfAbsent` right?

@guozhangwang updates per comments.
   

- Put `SubscriptionUpdates` back as inner class of `StreamPartitionAssignor`
- Removed integration test and added unit test
- Put the check for updated topics in the `StreamPartitionAssignor#onAssignment`

A quick update: 

The tests have revealed a bug: The `TxnOffsetCommitResponse` could have a `REQUEST_TIMED_OUT` error, which is retriable. The client did not handle this as a retriable error but instead considered it fatal and put the transaction manager in error state. 

The `TransactionalMessageCopier` would then get a `KafkaException` on the next transactional method it invoked. It would catch this exception, and log it to stderr, and exit. So the copy process would never finish. 

Unfortunately, due to an oversight in the python test code, we never collected the stderr stream from the message copier, so there was nothing suspicious in the logs collected. I only found this out because _very occasionally_ the background sender thread would run _before_ the process was shut down, detect that the transaction manager is in error state, and log it. Since we collected the transactional_message_copier logs (ie. the actual producer logs), I could get alerted to this issue .

I have now updated the code to both handle the REQUEST_TIMED_OUT error on the TxnOffsetCommitRequest (just like the `ConsumerCoordinator` does for the regular `OffsetCommitRequest`), and also collect the stderr log from the `TransactionalMessageCopier`. My testing so far shows that the test is stable after these changes.
